title-group.article-title: Leg Ulcers Associated With Giant Cell Arteritis Relapse

author-notes.corresp: Vera Tengattini, University of Bologna, Policlinico S. Orsola-Malpighi, U.O. Dermatologia, Via Massarenti, 1, 40138 Bologna, Italy. Email: vera.tengattini@hotmail.com

body.p: Giant cell arteritis (GCA) is a granulomatous vasculitis of the aorta and its major branches, with a predilection for the extracranial branches of the carotid artery.1 In June 2012, an 81-year-old Caucasian woman was referred to our dermatology service because of nonhealing ulcers on the right leg. The patient has a personal history of GCA diagnosed in 1991 and was treated with methotrexato and prednisone. She did not complain of asthenia, jaw claudication, and headache. On admission, her inflammatory markers were elevated: erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 52 mm/h and C-reactive protein level was 1.16 mg/dL. The rest of the laboratory tests and coagulative screening were within normal limits. On admission, she resumed methotrexate 5 mg/week, folic acid 5 mg/week, prednisone 5 mg/day, and pantoprazole 40 mg/day. On physical examination, we found 3 crusted leg ulcers surrounded with a zone of erythema (Figure 1). The patient underwent to a 3-mm punch biopsy of the lesions and an arteriovenous echo color Doppler of the leg. After debridement, the wound was dressed with medicated bandage. The histological finding was atypical for leg ulcers (Figure 2). We observed ulceration; granulation tissue; sparse, perivascular, interstitial mixed mostly lymphocytes; neutrophils; intraluminal thrombi; extravasated erythrocytes; and granulomatous infiltrate made up of histiocytes in the mid and reticular dermis. The ultrasonographic examination showed preserved vascular function and atherosclerosis of the right femoropopliteal arteries, even without significant stenosis. We made the diagnosis of leg ulcers associated with GCA relapse. After treatment with higher doses of systemic glucocorticoids, the ulcers improved in about 1 month.

caption.p: Three crusted leg ulcers surrounded with a zone of erythema on the right leg.
Extravasated erythrocytes, perivascular, granulomatous infiltrate made up of histiocytes in the mid and reticular dermis (hematoxylin–eosin 40×).

body.p: The histological features of GCA were first recognized in 1932 by Horton et al, and so is also called “Horton’s giant cell arteritis.”2 GCA usually occurs in individuals aged 50 years and older, more often in women.3 Genetic or ambient factors probably contribute to the development of GCA, but the etiology is still unknown.4 GCA is responsible for a broad spectrum of manifestations due to the inflammatory involvement of vessel wall with lymphocytic and macrophagic infiltrates in the tunica media that can extend from the tunica intima to the avventitia and sometimes involving internal elastic lamina. Giant cells can be present. Granulomas and fibrinoid necrosis are seen infrequently.3 Acute-phase reactants may be useful in the diagnosis and management of GCA. Up to 25% of biopsy-proven GCA has also elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Some data show the usefulness also of C-reactive protein and interleukin 6, a cytokine that induces acute-phase production in the liver, and it seems to be elevated in patients affected by GCA.3 The gold standard of GCA is histological diagnosis following biopsy of an affected artery, although negative biopsy does not exclude the diagnosis. GCA is sometimes associated (10% to 20% of cases) with polymyalgia rheumatica, a chronic syndrome of pain and stiffness, typically affecting proximal muscles of shoulder and pelvic girdle.4 Because of the similar histopathological findings in GCA, Takayasu’s arteritis, and polymyalgia rheumatica, some investigators believe they diseases are not separate entities but a continuum of disease.5 This matter is not completely settled. Scalp necrosis is uncommon in GCA, accounting for less the 1% of the cases, but it is the most frequent dermatologic manifestation of GCA.6 Vasculitis in GCA has been less frequently reported in the femoropopliteal arteries. Lower extremity arteries can be implicated in GCA, but symptomatic involvement, as in our case, is rare.7 To our knowledge, in the literature there is only one case of GCA presenting with leg ulcers.8

It is important to distinguish this rare entity from atherosclerotic peripheral vascular disease since the treatment is very different. If recognized early, it may be possible to avoid complications of the underlying disease by proper treatment with glucocorticoids. The improvement in our patient after therapy confirmed our diagnosis.
